Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, \u00a.proposition: This Honorable Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, § 28, as well as c. 209C, § 20, as the Court previously issued the Original Order regarding custody of the parties’ minor child.

c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Honorable Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, § 28, as well as c. 209C, § 20, as the Court previously issued the Original Order regarding custody of the parties’ minor child.

*See Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 84.proposition: A modification of the Original Order is necessary to align with the best interests of the child, which is the paramount consideration in custody matters under Massachusetts law.
*See Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 84.support_reasoning: The case strongly affirms that the best interests of the child are the paramount concern in Massachusetts custody determinations, but it does so in the context of an initial custody adjudication, not a modification of an existing order. The opinion expressly declines to apply the ‘substantial change in circumstances’ standard for modification and instead analyzes the case under G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a)’s best‑interests framework. Thus, while it is solid authority for the paramountcy of the best‑interests standard in custody matters, it is not authority for the proposition that a modification of an original order is necessary to align with those best interests.
*See Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 84.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… and has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., … Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’); … DeFerrari v. DeFerrari, 220 Mass. 38, 41 (1914) (custody award is subject to revision ‘as the best interests of the child may demand’).”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 598.proposition: A modification of the Original Order is necessary to align with the best interests of the child, which is the paramount consideration in custody matters under Massachusetts law.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 598.support_reasoning: The opinion is about remanding a custody case for additional findings on the effect of domestic violence; it does not expressly state that a ‘modification of the Original Order is necessary’ or frame the issue as a modification proceeding. While the court clearly treats the child’s best interests as central and requires explicit findings on domestic violence in making custody determinations, it does not itself order a change of custody based on that standard. Thus, it supports the broader idea that best interests are paramount in custody matters, but not the specific proposition that a modification of the Original Order is necessary in this case.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 598.relevant_excerpt: “Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking. … Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings…”

*See Ardizoni v. Raymond*, 40 Mass. App..raw_text: *See Ardizoni v. Raymond*, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734, 738 (1996)
*See Ardizoni v. Raymond*, 40 Mass. App..proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that parenting plans should reflect the changing developmental needs of children.
*See Ardizoni v. Raymond*, 40 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns standards for modifying custody (material and substantial change plus best interests of the children) and emphasizes keeping siblings, especially twins, together. It does not discuss parenting plans in terms of adjusting to children’s changing developmental stages or needs over time, nor does it articulate any general principle about parenting plans reflecting developmental change. The focus is on sibling unity and the weight to give children’s stated preferences, not developmental tailoring of parenting plans.
*See Ardizoni v. Raymond*, 40 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28… enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’… The list of factors within the judge’s purview in child custody matters includes a presumption generally favoring the placement of siblings under one roof.”

*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..proposition: Massachusetts law allows for modification of custody orders when a material change in circumstances is demonstrated.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly acknowledges that the father’s parental rights were not terminated and that the judge "clearly left open the possibility of a modification of his order precluding visitation," recognizing that custody and visitation orders are subject to later change. While the case is not a modification proceeding itself and does not use the phrase "material change in circumstances," Massachusetts law generally requires such a change for modification, and the court’s discussion presumes the modifiability of custody/visitation orders consistent with that framework. Thus the case indirectly supports the proposition that custody/visitation orders can be modified under Massachusetts law when circumstances warrant.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: Despite the judge’s decision documenting the father’s abuse of the mother and concluding that the father’s visitation with the child should be suspended, the judge did not terminate the father’s parental rights, and clearly left open the possibility of a modification of his order precluding visitation. In a case such as this, the father’s constitutional rights as a parent require that the judge considering a request for removal take into account the potential for the father to seek a resumption of visitation.

*See Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. C.raw_text: *See Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865, 872 (2006)
*See Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. C.proposition: The Court may consider a child’s evolving developmental needs and quality of life when evaluating whether modification is in the child’s best interests.
*See Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: The court, applying Yannas, restates that in determining a child’s best interests on a removal/modification request, the judge must consider whether the child’s quality of life may be improved by the change and how moving or not moving will affect the child’s developmental needs. This expressly authorizes consideration of the child’s evolving developmental needs and overall quality of life as part of the best‑interests analysis, which matches the proposition.
*See Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. C.relevant_excerpt: “In determining a child’s best interests, consideration must be given ‘to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.’ Yannas, 395 Mass. at 711.”

*See Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182.proposition: The stability, safety, and well-being of the child remain the controlling factors in custody modifications.
*See Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182.support_reasoning: The case is primarily about child support (treatment of Social Security disability dependency benefits and security/attachment of assets) and, secondarily, about the standards for modifying legal custody. While the opinion references the statutory "best interests of the child" standard for custody modifications, it does not articulate or emphasize "stability, safety, and well-being" as the controlling factors in custody modifications. The court instead focuses on the need for specific findings and that custody changes must be in the best interests of the child, so the quoted proposition overstates and reframes what the case actually says.
*See Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding "that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[]." ... However, we shall not sustain an award of custody "unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed."

*See Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 2.proposition: The child’s express desire for meaningful contact with both parents is an important consideration under Massachusetts law.
*See Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 2.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses multiple factors bearing on a child’s best interests—stability, foster and kin placements, sibling relationships, expert testimony—but it does not address, or even mention, the child’s *expressed* desires regarding contact with either parent. The key passage about children’s expressed wishes concerns siblings wanting to live together, not contact with parents, and it is cited only to emphasize that such wishes are not dispositive. Thus, the case does not stand for the proposition that a child’s express desire for meaningful contact with both parents is an important consideration under Massachusetts law.
*See Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219, 2.relevant_excerpt: “‘The courts of this Commonwealth have recognized the importance of siblings’ being raised together.’ Care & Protection of Three Minors, supra at 715, and cases cited. But we have been careful to observe that a sibling relationship is but one factor, albeit an important one, that a judge should consider in custody cases. See Care & Protection of Three Minors, supra (even where siblings spent time together and expressed desire to live together, sibling relationship is not dispositive).”
